revisions.rev:
{{Infobox NFL season | logo = | team = Miami Dolphins | year = 2008 | record = 11â5 | division_place = 1st [[AFC East]] | coach = [[Tony Sparano]] | general manager = [[Jeff Ireland]] | stadium = [[Dolphin Stadium]] | playoffs = Lost [[NFL playoffs, 2008â09|Wild Card Playoffs]] ([[Baltimore Ravens|Ravens]]) 27â9 | pro bowlers = 3 | uniform = Image:AFCE-Uniform-MIA.PNG }} The '''[[2008 NFL season|2008]] [[Miami Dolphins]] season''' was the organization's 39th season in the [[National Football League]] and 43rd overall.<ref>{{cite web|title = Miami Dolphins History|work = NFL-History.com|url = http://www.nfl-history.com/dolphins.php|accessdate =2008-01-02|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20090201202808/http://www.nfl-history.com/dolphins.php |archivedate = February 1, 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref> During the regular season the Dolphins completed the greatest single-season turnaround in NFL history,<ref>http://beatthesportsbook.com/home/?p=10901 {{Wayback|url=http://beatthesportsbook.com/home/?p=10901|date =20110707220437}}</ref><ref>http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/columnists/greg_cote/story/822086.html {{Wayback|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/columnists/greg_cote/story/822086.html|date =20110521234138}}</ref> going from a 1â15 regular season record in 2007 to an 11â5 record in 2008. The previous standard for improvement one year after a 1â15 season belonged to the 1992 Indianapolis Colts, who went 9â7. The 1999 Indianapolis Colts were the only other team to accomplish a 10-game turnaround, winning 13 games after winning 3 in 1998. Additionally, Miami won the [[AFC East]], becoming the first team in NFL history to win their division after only having one win the previous season.
The 2008 season was the first with [[Bill Parcells]] as Executive Vice President of Football Operations, [[Jeff Ireland]] as General Manager,<ref name="ParcellsHired">{{cite web|title = Parcells Era Begins In Miami; Injury Update|work = MiamiDolphins.com|url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5610|accessdate =2008-01-02|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080201032141/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5610 |archivedate = February 1, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="IrelandHired">{{cite web|title = Dolphins Name Jeff Ireland General Manager|work = MiamiDolphins.com|url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5620|accessdate =2008-01-02|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080219142007/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5620 |archivedate = February 19, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> and [[Tony Sparano]] as [[head coach]].<ref name="CameronFired">{{cite web|title = Dolphins Make Coaching Change|work = MiamiDolphins.com|url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5622|accessdate =2008-01-03|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080331093330/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5622 |archivedate = March 31, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="SparanoHired">{{cite web|title = Tony Sparano Becomes Eighth Head Coach In Dolphins History|work = MiamiDolphins.com|url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5637|accessdate =2008-01-16|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080120145140/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5637 |archivedate = January 20, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
With a league-worst 1â15 record in 2007,<ref name="2007standings">{{cite web|title = 2007 NFL Regular Season Standings|work = NFL.com|url = http://www.nfl.com/standings?category=div&season=2007-REG&split=Overall|accessdate = 2008-03-03}}</ref> the Dolphins held the first pick in the [[2008 NFL Draft]] and selected [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] [[offensive tackle]] [[Jake Long]]. The offseason also saw the departure of two [[Pro Bowl]]ers and long-time Dolphins with the release of [[linebacker]] [[Zach Thomas]] and trade of [[defensive end]] [[Jason Taylor (American football)|Jason Taylor]].
{{TOC limit|limit=3}}
==Offseason personnel moves== ===Front office=== On December 27, 2007, Dolphins owner [[Wayne Huizenga]] hired former NFL head coach and [[ESPN]] analyst [[Bill Parcells]] as Executive Vice President of Football Operations.<ref name="ParcellsHired" /> Parcells signed a four-year deal with the Dolphins less than a day after turning down a similar offer from the [[Atlanta Falcons]].<ref name="ParcellsFalcons">{{cite web | title = Parcells signs four-year deal to head Dolphins' football operations | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3162909 | accessdate = 2 January 2008 }}</ref>
Just a few days after Parcells' hiring, three men were dismissed from the Dolphins' front office.<ref name="MuellerFired">{{cite web | title = Three Leave Dolphins | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5617 | accessdate = 2 January 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080103113349/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5617 |archivedate = January 3, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The most notable of which was general manager [[Randy Mueller]], who was hired by the team in 2005.<ref name="MuellerHired">{{cite news | title = Randy Mueller hired as Dolphins GM | work = USAToday.com | url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/dolphins/2005-06-06-mueller-hired_x.htm | accessdate = 2 January 2008 | date=2005-06-06}}</ref> Also dismissed were Assistant Director of Player Personnel Mike Baugh and College Scouting Coordinator Rick Thompson.<ref name="MuellerFired" />
Three days after Mueller's dismissal, Parcells hired [[Jeff Ireland]] as the team's new general manager.<ref name="IrelandHired" /> Ireland had worked for the [[Dallas Cowboys]] the past seven years, including the last three as Vice President of College and Pro Scouting.<ref name="IrelandHired" /> Ireland had worked with Parcells previously, when the latter was head coach of the Cowboys from 2003 to 2006.<ref name="IrelandHired" /> Although Ireland was officially given final say on personnel decisions, it was speculated that Parcells was actually in control, and did not hold the title of General Manager so that the team may hire a front office executive from another team.<ref name="FinalSay">{{cite web | title = Tuna helper on the menu for afternoon introduction | work = DolphinsInDeth.blogspot.com | url = http://dolphinsindepth.blogspot.com/2007/12/tuna-helper-on-menu-for-afternoon.html | accessdate = 6 January 2008 }}</ref>
On January 15, the Dolphins reeled in another former Cowboys executive when they hired [[Brian Gaine]] as Assistant Director of Player Personnel.<ref name="BrianGaine">{{cite web | title = Brian Gaine Named Assistant Director Of Player Personnel | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5634 | accessdate = 16 January 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080119103615/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5634 |archivedate = January 19, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Gaine had previously spent the past three seasons as the Cowboys' Assistant Director of Pro Scouting, working with both Parcells and Ireland during that time.<ref name="BrianGaine" />
Following the [[2008 NFL Draft]], it was reported on May 1 that the Dolphins had fired scouts [[Ellis Rainsberger]], [[Jack Glowik]] and [[Roger Pollard]].<ref name="ScoutsFired">{{cite web | title = Fins Firing Scouts | work = ProFootballTalk.com | url = http://www.profootballtalk.com/2008/05/01/fins-firing-scouts/ | accessdate = 5 May 2008 }}</ref> The team's vice president of media relations, [[Harvey Greene]], said Rainsberger had retired and did not comment on the other two reported firings.<ref name="ScoutsFired"/>
===Coaches=== ====Head coach==== Just one day after hiring of [[Jeff Ireland]] as general manager, the Dolphins fired head coach [[Cam Cameron]] after just one season on the job.<ref name="CameronFired" /> Cameron led the Dolphins to an NFL worst 1â15 record in 2007, which was also the worst in franchise history.<ref name="nfl">{{cite web | title = 2007 NFL Regular Season Standings | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/standings?category=div&season=2007-REG&split=Overall | accessdate = 3 January 2008 }}</ref><ref name="2007record">{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins Team Encyclopedia | work = pro-football-reference.com | url = http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/mia/ | accessdate = 3 January 2008 }}</ref> Additionally, all but two members of the coaching staff were dismissed.<ref name="CameronFired" /> The only coaches retained were assistant special teams coach [[Steve Hoffman (American football)|Steve Hoffman]] and linebackers coach [[George Edwards (American football)|George Edwards]].<ref name="CameronFired" /> Both Hoffman and Edwards were coaches for the [[Dallas Cowboys]] during Ireland's tenure with the team.<ref name="IrelandHired" /><ref name="HoffmanBio">{{cite web | title = Profile â Steve Hoffman | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/team/coachingstaff/coachingstaff_hoffman_s.asp | accessdate = 3 January 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071019161508/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/team/coachingstaff/coachingstaff_hoffman_s.asp |archivedate = October 19, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="EdwardsBio">{{cite web | title = Profile â George Edwards | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/team/coachingstaff/coachingstaff_edwards_g.asp | accessdate = 3 January 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20090226012635/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/team/coachingstaff/coachingstaff_edwards_g.asp |archivedate = February 26, 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
A search for Cameron's replacement began almost immediately after his firing.<ref name="CoachSearch">{{cite web | title = Dolphins can Cameron, search for new coach | work = Herald.com | url = http://www.miamiherald.com/616/story/365360.html | accessdate = 4 January 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20110521211430/http://www.miamiherald.com/616/story/365360.html |archivedate = May 21, 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Various candidates were rumored, many of which had some connection to Parcells and/or Ireland.<ref name="ClaytonCandidates">{{cite web | title = Parcells wants his own guy, so Cameron's out | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/columns/story?columnist=clayton_john&id=3178799 | accessdate = 4 January 2008 }}</ref> Rumored candidates included [[Cleveland Browns]] head coach [[Romeo Crennel]], [[Dallas Cowboys]] assistant [[Tony Sparano]], Cowboys secondary coach [[Todd Bowles]], [[Arizona Cardinals]] running backs coach [[Maurice Carthon]] and Cardinals offensive coordinator [[Todd Haley]].<ref name="ClaytonCandidates" /> Additionally, [[Baltimore Ravens]] defensive coordinator [[Rex Ryan]] and [[Minnesota Vikings]] defensive coordinator [[Leslie Frazier]] were contacted.<ref name="RyanContacted">{{cite web | title = Dolphins contact Rex Ryan | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/football/pro/dolphins/sfl-dolryan010307,0,2496419.story | accessdate = 4 January 2008 }}</ref><ref name="FrazierInterview">{{cite web | title = Dolphins will interview Vikings' Frazier | work = Herald.com | url = http://www.miamiherald.com/616/story/366020.html | accessdate = 4 January 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20110521211446/http://www.miamiherald.com/616/story/366020.html |archivedate = May 21, 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' suggested that [[Washington Redskins]] defensive coordinator [[Gregg Williams]] could be a candidate as well.<ref name="GreggWilliamsRumor">{{cite news | title = Taylor's Dad Thanks Team for Its Support | work = WashingtonPost.com | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/01/06/AR2008010602038.html | accessdate = 7 January 2008 | first1=Paul | last1=Tenorio | first2=Jason | last2=Reid | date=2008-01-07}}</ref>
The first interview scheduled was Sparano, who met with the Dolphins on Saturday, January 11.<ref name="SparanoInterview">{{cite web | title = Dolphins to interview Sparano Saturday | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/football/pro/dolphins/sfl-0104sporano,0,5058179.story?coll=sofla_tab01_layout | accessdate = 4 January 2008 }}</ref> Sparano had previously met with the [[Atlanta Falcons]] and [[Baltimore Ravens]] regarding their head coaching vacancies.<ref name="SparanoWillAccept">{{cite web | title = Source: Sparano will take Dolphins job | work = NHRegister.com | url = http://www.nhregister.com/WebApp/appmanager/JRC/BigDaily?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=pg_article&r21.content=/MAIN_REP/Article/2008/01/05/1373966 | accessdate = 6 January 2008 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> On January 6, it was reported that Sparano would be offered the Dolphins' head coaching job, and that he would accept.<ref name="SparanoWillAccept" /> The Dolphins denied the report later that day, saying it was an initial interview only and that the team had interviews with others planned over the next few days.<ref name="DenySparanoReport">{{cite web | title = Dolphins deny report they offered Sparano coaching job | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/football/pro/dolphins/sfl-doldeny010607,0,1976725.story | accessdate = 7 January 2008 }}</ref> However, the addition of quarterbacks coach [[David Lee (American football coach)|David Lee]], a former Cowboys assistant, fueled speculation that Sparano was indeed going to the next head coach of the Miami Dolphins.<ref name="DavidLeeHired">{{cite web | title = Dolphins hire QB coach with tie to Cowboys | work = Herald.com | url = http://www.miamiherald.com/616/story/370080.html | accessdate = 7 January 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20110521211450/http://www.miamiherald.com/616/story/370080.html |archivedate = May 21, 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="PFTLeeSpeculation">{{cite web | title = Fins situation gets even fishier | work = ProFootballTalk.com | url = http://beta.profootballtalk.com/2008/01/07/fins-situation-gets-even-fishier/ | accessdate = 7 January 2008 }}</ref>
The team then proceeded to interview Frazier, Ryan and [[Tennessee Titans]] defensive coordinator [[Jim Schwartz]].<ref name="FrazierRyan">{{cite web | title = Ryan interviews with Dolphins after talking to Ravens | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3187335 | accessdate = 16 January 2008 }}</ref><ref name="SchwartzInterview">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Confirm Interview With Schwartz | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5632 | accessdate = 16 January 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080118133522/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5632 |archivedate = January 18, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> After the [[Dallas Cowboys]] lost to the [[New York Giants]] in the divisional round of the [[NFL playoffs, 2007-08#NFC: New York Giants 21, Dallas Cowboys 17|2007 NFL playoffs]] on January 13,<ref name="CowboysLoss">{{cite web | title = NFL Game Center: Post Game â New York Giants at Dallas Cowboys â 2007 Division Playoffs | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter?season=2007&week=POST20&game_id=29523 | accessdate = 16 January 2008 }}</ref> speculation grew that Sparano's hiring was imminent.<ref name="SparanoESPN">{{cite web | title = Of four candidates, Cowboys' Sparano out front for Dolphins job | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3196640 | accessdate = 16 January 2008 }}</ref><ref name="SparanoSalgueroBlog">{{cite web | title = Pieces fall into place for Dolphins hiring of coach | work = Herald.com | url = http://dolphinsindepth.blogspot.com/2008/01/pieces-fall-into-place-for-dolphins.html | accessdate = 16 January 2008 }}</ref> On January 16, the Dolphins ended their search by naming Sparano the eighth head coach in franchise history.<ref name="SparanoHired" /> He received a four-year contract believed to be worth between $2.5 and $2.7 million per season.<ref name="SparanoContract">{{cite web | title = Dolphins hire Sparano as head coach, replacing Cameron | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3199065 | accessdate = 17 January 2008 }}</ref>
====Assistants==== Parcells and Ireland made their first coaching staff addition on January 7, luring [[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss]] offensive coordinator [[David Lee (American football coach)|David Lee]] to be [[quarterback]]s coach.<ref name="DavidLeeHired" /> Lee, who briefly followed [[Houston Nutt]] to Ole Miss after serving as his offensive coordinator at [[Arkansas Razorbacks football|Arkansas]] in 2007, worked with Parcells and Ireland as the Cowboys' quarterbacks coach from 2003 to 2006.<ref name="DavidLeeHired" /> The addition fueled speculation that Sparano was indeed going to the next head coach of the Miami Dolphins.<ref name="DavidLeeHired" /><ref name="PFTLeeSpeculation" />
Two days after hiring Sparano as their head coach, the Dolphins made their second assistance coach hiring. On January 18, [[Mike Maser]] was named the team's new offensive line coach. Maser had previously served in the same capacity for the [[Carolina Panthers]] from 2003 to 2006, and worked with Sparano when both were assistants for the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] in 2002.
Over the next week, the Dolphins filled various positions on Sparano's staff. On January 22, former [[Kansas City Chiefs]] running backs coach [[James Saxon (American football)|James Saxon]] was hired in the same capacity for the Dolphins.<ref name="SaxsonMarcus">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Add Marcus And Saxon To Coaching Staff | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5646 | accessdate = 12 February 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080229044800/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5646 |archivedate = February 29, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Also hired that day was former [[Atlanta Falcons]] strength and conditioning coach [[Evan Marcus]], who took the same job with Miami.<ref name="SaxsonMarcus" />
On January 23, the Dolphins added four more assistant coaches to their staff when they named [[Paul Pasqualoni]] as their defensive coordinator, [[Todd Bowles]] as assistant head coach/secondary, [[Kacy Rodgers]] as defensive line coach and [[David Corrao]] as defensive quality control coach.<ref name="FourCoachesHired">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Add Four Coaches To Staff | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5650 | accessdate = 12 February 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080221183736/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5650 |archivedate = February 21, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Pasqualoni, Bowles and Rodgers all came from the [[Dallas Cowboys]]' staff, while Corrao was most recently linebackers coach at the [[Ole Miss Rebels|University of Mississippi]].<ref name="FourCoachesHired" />
A day later, former [[UCLA Bruins football|UCLA]] head coach [[Karl Dorrell]] was named the team's new wide receivers coach.<ref name="DorrellHired">{{cite web | title = Karl Dorrell Named Dolphins' Wide Receivers Coach | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5652 | accessdate = 12 February 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080229044805/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5652 |archivedate = February 29, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Five more coaches were added to the staff on January 28 when the Dolphins named [[John Bonamego]] as their special teams coordinator, [[George DeLeone]] as their tight ends coach, [[David Puloka]] as assistant strength and conditioning coach, [[Jim Reid (American football)|Jim Reid]] as outside linebackers coach and [[Steve Bush (coach)|Steve Bush]] as offensive quality control coach.<ref name="FiveCoachesHired">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Hire Five Coaches | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5657 | accessdate = 12 February 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080201143022/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5657 |archivedate = February 1, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
The Dolphins made their final addition to the staff on February 4, hiring [[Dan Henning]] as offensive coordinator.<ref name="HenningHired">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Tab Dan Henning As Offensive Coordinator | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5670 | accessdate = 12 February 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080209120547/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5670 |archivedate = February 9, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Henning, who had most recently served as offensive coordinator for the [[Carolina Panthers]] from 2002 to 2006, had previous worked for the Dolphins under [[Don Shula]] as quarterbacks and wide receivers coach in 1979â1980.<ref name="HenningHired" />
====Final staff==== When the Dolphins' coaching staff was completed with the hiring of offensive coordinator [[Dan Henning]] on February 14, only two of the 17 assistant coaches under Sparano (Edwards and Hoffman) were holdovers from the previous season's staff.<ref name="StaffComplete">{{cite web | title = Sparano Completes Staff Of "Idea People" | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5676 | accessdate = 12 February 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080211064616/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5676 |archivedate = February 11, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Three of the new coaches (Bowles, Pasqualoni and Rodgers) had experience with Parcells, Ireland and Sparano in Dallas.<ref name="StaffComplete" /> The completed staff was as follows: {| class="toccolours" style="text-align: left;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background:#066; color:white; text-align:center;"|'''2008 Miami Dolphins staff''' |- | colspan="7" style="text-align:right;"| |- |valign="top"| | style="font-size:95%; vertical-align:top;"| '''Head Coaches''' * Head Coach â [[Tony Sparano]] * Assistant Head Coach/Secondary â [[Todd Bowles]]
'''Offensive Coaches''' * Offensive Coordinator â [[Dan Henning]] * Quarterbacks â [[David Lee (American football coach)|David Lee]] * Running Backs â [[James Saxon (American football)|James Saxon]] * Wide Receivers â [[Karl Dorrell]] * Tight Ends â [[George DeLeone]] * Offensive Line â [[Mike Maser]] * Offensive Quality Control â [[Steve Bush (coach)|Steve Bush]] |width="35"|  |valign="top"| | style="font-size:95%; vertical-align:top;"| '''Defensive Coaches''' * Defensive Coordinator â [[Paul Pasqualoni]] * Defensive Line â [[Kacy Rodgers]] * Inside Linebackers â [[George Edwards (American football)|George Edwards]] * Outside Linebackers â [[Jim Reid (American football)|Jim Reid]] * Defensive Quality Control â [[David Corrao]]
'''Special Teams Coaches''' * Special Teams Coordinator â [[John Bonamego]] * Kicking â [[Steve Hoffman (American football)|Steve Hoffman]]
'''Strength and Conditioning''' * Head Strength and Conditioning â [[Evan Marcus]] * Strength and Conditioning Assistant â [[David Puloka]] </div> |}
===Players=== ====Departures==== * '''February 11''' â Terminated the contracts of quarterback [[Trent Green]], wide receiver [[Marty Booker]], offensive tackle [[L. J. Shelton]] and defensive tackle [[Keith Traylor]].<ref name="NineCut">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Release Nine Players | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5681 | accessdate = 12 February 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080214171130/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5681 |archivedate = February 14, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> * '''February 11''' â Waived offensive tackle [[Anthony Alabi]], offensive tackle [[Marion Dukes]], guard [[Marquay Love]], offensive lineman [[Joe Toledo]] and defensive tackle [[Anthony Bryant (American football)|Anthony Bryant]].<ref name="NineCut" /> * '''February 14''' â Released linebacker [[Zach Thomas]].<ref name="ZachReleased">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Release Zach Thomas | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5685 | accessdate = 29 February 2008 |archiveurl = (linebacker)|Mark Washington]] and wide receiver [[Chandler Williams]].<ref name="April24EightCut">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Release Eight Players | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = Worrell]], who tore his [[Anterior cruciate ligament|ACL]] in 2007,<ref name="WorrellACL">{{cite web | title = Dolphins safety Worrell out with torn ACL | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3140206 | accessdate = 24 April 2008 }}</ref> after he failed a physical.<ref name="April24EightCut"/> * '''April 29''' â Released quarterback [[Matt Baker (American football)|Matt Baker]] and defensive tackle [[Steve Fifita]].<ref name="BakerFifita">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Release Fifita And Baker | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = [[Marcel Reece]], defensive end [[Derreck Robinson]], linebacker [[Abraham Wright]] and cornerback [[Aaron Lane]]. Reece and Lane were signed as [[undrafted free agent]]s the previous week, while Robinson and Wright were with the Dolphins in 2007.<ref name="RobinsonWright">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Sign Two; Release Four | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5806 | accessdate = 5 May 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080508164600/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5806 |archivedate = May 8, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> * '''May 16''' â Waived offensive lineman [[Drew Mormino]] after he failed a physical.<ref name="MorminoWaived">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Cut OL Drew Mormino | work = PalmBeachPost.com | url = http://www.palmbeachpost.com/blogs/content/shared-blogs/palmbeach/miamidolphins/entries/2008/05/16/dolphins_cut_ol_drew_mormino.html | accessdate = 16 May 2008 }}</ref> Mormino spent the 2007 season on [[injured reserve]] with a shoulder injury.<ref name="MorminoWaived"/> * '''June 6''' â Released placekicker [[Dave Rayner]].

====2008 NFL Draft==== Due to their league-worst 1â15 record in 2007,<ref name="2007standings"/> the Dolphins secured the first overall pick in the [[2008 NFL Draft]] on April 26.<ref name="FirstOverallPick">{{cite web | title = 2008 NFL Draft order | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/draft/story?id=09000d5d805a3a57&template=without-video&confirm=true | accessdate = 3 March 2008 }}</ref> The Dolphins used it to draft [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]] [[offensive tackle]] [[Jake Long]].

7 !! 245 | [[Lionel Dotson]]|| [[Defensive end]] || [[Arizona Wildcats football|Arizona]] || 6' 4" || 295 lbs |} '''Notes''' * The Dolphins own second-round pick, the first of the round, was the 32nd overall in the draft rather than the 33rd because the [[New England Patriots]] forfeited their first-round pick (31st overall) after the [[2007 National Football League videotaping controversy|Spygate]] incident.<ref name="FirstOverallPick" /> * The Dolphins acquired a second-round pick from the [[San Diego Chargers]] in a trade that sent [[wide receiver]] [[Chris Chambers]] to San Diego on October 16, 2007.<ref name="ChambersTrade">{{cite web | title = Chargers trade for Chris Chambers | work = Scout.com | url = http://sdg.scout.com/2/691409.html | accessdate = 3 March 2008 }}</ref> * The Dolphins sent their fifth-round pick to the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] in exchange for [[quarterback]] [[Trent Green]] on June 5, 2007.<ref name="GreenAcquired">{{cite web | title = Green goes to Dolphins from Chiefs in trade | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2894600 | accessdate = 3 March 2008 }}</ref> * The Dolphins and [[Dallas Cowboys]] swapped sixth-round draft picks in trade that brought [[defensive tackle]] [[Jason Ferguson]] to Miami.<ref name="FergusonAcquired" /> * The last of the Dolphins' picks in the sixth and seventh rounds were awarded by NFL due to free agents lost the previous offseason.<ref name="CompensatoryPicks" />
=====Draft day trades===== On the first day of the draft, the Dolphins traded second-year running back [[Lorenzo Booker]] to the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] in exchange for a fourth-round pick (115th overall) in the [[2008 NFL Draft]].<ref name="BookerToEagles">{{cite web | title = Eagles give up first-round draft pick, acquire RB Booker from 'Fins | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/draft/story?id=09000d5d807ff74b&template=without-video&confirm=true | accessdate = 5 May 2008 }}</ref>
On the second day of the draft, the Dolphins acquired the [[Detroit Lions]]' third-round pick (66th overall) as well as their sixth-round pick (176th overall) in exchange for the Dolphins' third-round pick (64th overall).<ref name="LionsTrade">{{cite web | title = Lions take RB K. Smith to start third round | work = Rotoworld.com | url = http://www.rotoworld.com/content/playerpages/playerbreakingnews.asp?sport=NFL&id=4638&line=115661&spln=1 | accessdate = 25 May 2008 }}</ref> The Lions used the pick to select running back [[Kevin Smith (running back)|Kevin Smith]],<ref name="LionsTrade"/> while the Dolphins took defensive end [[Kendall Langford]] with the third-round pick and running back [[Jalen Parmele]] with the sixth-rounder.<ref name="NFLDraftTades"/>
Later on Day 2, the Dolphins traded the fourth-round pick acquired from the Eagles, along with a seventh-round pick (208th overall), to the [[Chicago Bears]] in exchange for the 110th overall selection.<ref name="NFLDraftTades">{{cite web | title = 2008 NFL Draft Trades | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=nfl&id=3371483 | accessdate = 25 May 2008 }}</ref> The Dolphins used this pick to select guard [[Shawn Murphy (American football)|Shawn Murphy]].<ref name="NFLDraftTades"/> The 115th overall pick was eventually dealt by the Bears the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]], who used it to select defensive tackle [[Dre Moore]].<ref name="NFLDraftTades"/> The Bears used the seventh-round pick to select defensive end [[Ervin Baldwin]].<ref name="NFLDraftTades"/>
=====Draft pick signings===== In the weeks leading up to the draft, the Dolphins began contract negotiations with Jake Long.<ref name="JakeLongNegotiations">{{cite web | title = Dolphins begin contract talks with potential No. 1s Long, Gholston | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/football/pro/dolphins/sfl-flspdolphins10sbapr10,0,7093217.story | accessdate = 13 April 2008 }}</ref> On April 14, [[Peter King (sportswriter)|Peter King]] of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' reported that the Dolphins had given Long a deadline to accept their contract offer (believed to be worth less than [[2007 NFL Draft|2007]] No. 1 pick [[JaMarcus Russell]] received from the [[Oakland Raiders]]); otherwise, they would move on to another prospect.<ref name="JakeLongDeadline">{{cite news | title = Monday Morning QB | work = SI.com | url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2008/writers/peter_king/04/14/draft/1.html | accessdate = 14 April 2008 | date=2008-04-14}}</ref> On April 22, the Dolphins officially signed Long to a five-year, $57.75 million contract with $30 million guaranteed, assuring they would take him first overall.<ref name="LongContract">{{cite web | title = Dolphins sign Long, will select OT No. 1 overall | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/draft08/news/story?id=3358424&campaign=rss&source=NFLHeadlines | accessdate = 5 May 2008 }}</ref> On May 19, the Dolphins signed sixth-rounders [[Jalen Parmele]] and [[Lex Hilliard]] and seventh-rounder [[Lionel Dotson]] to contacts.<ref name="McKinneySigned"/> On May 23, sixth-round pick [[Donald Thomas (American football)|Donald Thomas]] was signed to a multi-year deal.<ref name="DThomasSigned">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Sign Donald Thomas | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5829 | accessdate = 25 May 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080528041353/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5829 |archivedate = May 28, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> On July 11, the Dolphins signed third-round pick Kendall Langford to a multi-year deal.
====Undrafted free agents==== Following the [[2008 NFL Draft]], the Dolphins signed 18 [[undrafted free agent]]s. 14 November 2008 }}</ref> * '''August 30''' â Traded quarterback [[Josh McCown]] to the [[Carolina Panthers]] in exchange for a seventh-round pick in the [[2009 NFL Draft]].<ref name="AUGtrans"/>
====Final cuts==== On August 30, the Dolphins made 17 roster moves to reach the NFL's 53-player limit.<ref name="FinalCuts">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Make Roster Moves, Pare Down To 53 | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6005 | accessdate = 14 November 2008 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080914014957/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6005 |archivedate = September 14, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The players released were:<ref name="FinalCuts"/> {| |- |valign="top"| * Cornerback [[Will Billingsley]] * Linebacker [[Titus Brown]] * Safety [[Courtney Bryan]] * Center [[Michael Byrne (American football)|Michael Byrne]] * Wide receiver [[Jayson Foster]] * Linebacker [[Maurice Fountain]] * Linebacker [[Junior Glymph]] * Offensive tackle [[Daren Heerspink]] * Running back [[Lex Hilliard]] |valign="top"| * Fullback [[Reagan Maui'a]] * Linebacker [[Edmond Miles]] * Tight end [[Matthew Mulligan]] * Tight end [[Justin Peelle]] * Linebacker [[Kelly Poppinga]] * Guard [[Pedro Sosa]] * Center [[Matt Spanos]] * Defensive tackle [[Anthony Toribio]] |}

===Preseason recap=== After losing their preseason opener to the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]],<ref name="PreseasonResults">{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins 2008 Preseason Schedule | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/teams/schedule?team=MIA&season=2008&seasonType=PRE | accessdate = 14 November 2008 }}</ref> the Dolphins won their final three contests to finish the preseason 3â1.<ref name="PreseasonResults"/>
[[Quarterback]] [[Chad Pennington]] was the Dolphins' most efficient passer of the preseason, leading the team in completion percentage (72.0) and passer rating (104.8).<ref name="PreseasonStats">{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins 2008 Preseason Statistics | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/teams/statistics?season=2008&team=MIA&seasonType=PRE | accessdate = 14 November 2008 }}</ref> Rookie quarterback [[Chad Henne]] led the team in passing yards (351) but also in interceptions (2) while matching Pennington in passing touchdowns (1).<ref name="PreseasonStats"/>
[[Running back]]s [[Ricky Williams]] and [[Jalen Parmele]] tied for the team lead in rushing yards at 123.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> Williams, Parmele and [[Ronnie Brown]] were the only Dolphins to rush for a touchdown during the preseason, scoring one each.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> [[Lex Hilliard]] and [[Patrick Cobbs]] finished fourth and fifth, respectively, on the team in rushing yards.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/>
No Dolphins player surpassed 100 receiving yards during the preseason, though [[wide receiver]] [[Ted Ginn, Jr.]] came closest at 97.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> He also tied rookie [[Davone Bess]] for the team lead in receptions with eight.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> [[Tight end]]s [[Anthony Fasano]] and [[Sean Ryan (American football)|Sean Ryan]] were the only Dolphins to catch a touchdown pass.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/><ref name="SaintsRecap">{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins at New Orleans Saints â 2008 Preseason Week 4 | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter?game_id=29840&displayPage=tab_gamecenter&season=2008&week=PRE4 | accessdate = 14 November 2008 }}</ref>
On special teams, rookie [[placekicker]] [[Dan Carpenter]] converted 7-of-8 field-goal attempts and all six extra-point attempts.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> [[Punter (American football)|Punter]] [[Brandon Fields]] punted 21 times for a 44.1-yard average and two touchbacks.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> Meanwhile, Davone Bess led the team in punt returns (6) but Ted Ginn, Jr. was the only Dolphins player to return a kick or punt for a touchdown.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> Patrick Cobbs led the team in kick return yards with 106.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/>
On defense, [[Linebacker]]s [[Akin Ayodele]] and [[Reggie Torbor]] tied for the team lead with 17 tackles,<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> while Ayodele led the team in solo stops with 12.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> Five others â [[Yeremiah Bell]], [[Channing Crowder]], [[Renaldo Hill]], [[Nathan Jones (American football)|Nathan Jones]], [[Edmond Miles]] â also reached double-digits in tackles.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/>
Four players â [[Jason Allen (American football)|Jason Allen]], Renaldo Hill, [[Michael Lehan]], [[Joey Thomas]] â recorded an interception during the preseason.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> The Dolphins also totaled 14 quarterbacks sacks during the preseason.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> [[Linebacker]] [[Rob Ninkovich]] and [[defensive end]] [[Randy Starks]] each record a team-high two sacks,<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> while ten other players each recorded a sack apiece.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/> Channing Crowder, [[Junior Glymph]] and [[Paul Soliai]] each forced a fumble during the preseason.<ref name="PreseasonStats"/>

===Game summaries=== ====Week 1: vs. New York Jets==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Jets''' |R1=7 |R2=6 |R3=7 |R4=0 |RT=20 |Home=Dolphins |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=0 |H4=7 |HT=14 |stadium= [[Dolphin Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 88Â° Mostly Sunny |attendance= 65,859 |referee= [[Mike Carey (American football)|Mike Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Jim Nantz]] & [[Phil Simms]] }}
====Week 2: at Arizona Cardinals==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=3 |R4=7 |RT=10 |Home='''Cardinals''' |H1=14 |H2=3 |H3=14 |H4=0 |HT=31 |stadium= [[University of Phoenix Stadium]], [[Glendale, Arizona]] |time= 4:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= None (Dome Closed) |attendance= 63,445 |referee= [[Carl Cheffers]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Bill Macatee]] & [[Steve Beuerlein]] }}
====Week 3: at New England Patriots==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Dolphins''' |R1=7 |R2=14 |R3=7 |R4=10 |RT=38 |Home=Patriots |H1=0 |H2=6 |H3=7 |H4=0 |HT=13 |stadium= [[Gillette Stadium]], [[Foxborough, Massachusetts]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 72 Â°F Sunny |attendance= 68,756 |referee= [[Bill Carollo]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] & [[Solomon Wilcots]] }} The Dolphins headed to Foxboro to face the Division rival New England Patriots. Little did New England know that they would be a test for an offensive formation concocted as the Dolphins coaching staff wanted to put running backs [[Ricky Williams]] and [[Ronnie Brown]] onto the field at the same time. David Lee thus revealed the ''[[Wildcat formation|Wildcat]]'' to the NFL. [[Ronnie Brown]] would take direct snaps and keep it himself or hand it of to another back. The Dolphins decimated the Patriots all day with the Wildcat offense for a 38â13 victory.

====Week 12: vs. New England Patriots==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Patriots''' |R1=3||R2=14||R3=14||R4=17||RT=48 |Home=Dolphins |H1=7||H2=7||H3=7||H4=7||HT=28 |stadium= [[Dolphin Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 1:00 p.m. EST |weather= 73 Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Greg Gumbel]] (play-by-play) and [[Dan Dierdorf]] (color commentator) |referee= [[Alberto Riveron]] |attendance= 67,176 }}
A week after a 400-yard passing game against the Jets [[Matt Cassel]] threw for 415 yards and three touchdowns while [[Chad Pennington]] threw for 345 yards and two scores; both quarterbacks also ran in a touchdown. The Dolphins ''Wildcat'' offense was limited to 27 yards as the Patriots broke open a tight game in the fourth quarter, winning 48â28.

====Week 17: at New York Jets==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Dolphins''' |R1=0 |R2=14 |R3=7 |R4=3 |Home=Jets |H1=0 |H2=9 |H3=8 |H4=0 |stadium= [[Giants Stadium|The Meadowlands]], [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]] |time= 4:15 PM [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 65 Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 79,454 |referee= [[Bill Leavy]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Jim Nantz]] and [[Phil Simms]] }} The Dolphins clinched the [[AFC East]] title as they intercepted Jets quarterback [[Brett Favre]] three times ([[Philip Merling]] ran in a 25-yard touchdown on a Favre pick) while [[Charlie Anderson]] and [[Patrick Cobbs]] blocked a Jets punt. The win put the Dolphins into the playoffs for the first time since 2001.

===Awards and honors=== ====Coaches==== After leading the Dolphins to an 11â5 record and an [[AFC East]] title in his first year as head coach, [[Tony Sparano]] was selected as the [[National Football League Alumni|NFL Alumni]]'s 2008 Coach of the Year.<ref name="AlumniCoach">{{cite web | title = NFL Alumni Selects Tony Sparano As Its 2008 Coach Of The Year | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6316 | accessdate = 19 January 2009 }} {{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref> Sparano was also one of six nominees for the [[National Football League Coach of the Year Award|2008 Motorola NFL Coach of the Year Award]].<ref name="MotorolaCoach">{{cite web | title = Tony Sparano Nominated For Motorola NFL Coach Of The Year | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6318 | accessdate = 19 January 2009 }} {{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref>
====Players==== The Dolphins landed two players â running back [[Ronnie Brown]] and linebacker [[Joey Porter]] â on the [[American Football Conference|AFC]]'s [[2009 Pro Bowl|Pro Bowl]] team.<ref name="ProBowl">{{cite web | title = Porter Named Starter On AFC Pro Bowl Squad; Brown Also Selected | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6264&lid=6264 | accessdate = 19 January 2009 }} {{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref> Porter recorded 17.5 sacks during the 2008 season and was named as a starter on the AFC's squad.<ref name="ProBowl"/> In his first career Pro Bowl season, Brown led the Dolphins with 214 carries, 916 rushing yards and 10 rushing touchdowns.<ref name="2008RegSeasonStats">{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins 2008 Regular Season Stats | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/teams/miamidolphins/statistics?season=2008&team=MIA&seasonType=REG | accessdate = 19 January 2009 }}</ref> He also ranked fourth on the team with 33 catches and sixth with 254 receiving yards.<ref name="2008RegSeasonStats"/>
Additionally, Porter was nominated for the GMC Sierra Defensive Player of the Year Award and was a second-team [[Associated Press|AP]] [[All-Pro]] selection.<ref name="GMCSierraDPOY">{{cite web | title = Joey Porter Nominated For GMC Sierra Defensive Player Of The Year | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6313 | accessdate = 19 January 2009 }} {{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref><ref name="AllPro">{{cite web | title = Porter Named 2nd Team AP All-Pro | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6319 | accessdate = 19 January 2009 }} {{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref> Quarterback [[Chad Pennington]], guard [[Justin Smiley]] and cornerback [[Will Allen (cornerback)|Will Allen]] also received votes for the All-Pro team but were not selected.<ref name="AllPro"/>
However, Pennington did earn the [[National Football League Comeback Player of the Year Award|NFL Comeback Player of the Year Award]] for the second time in his career.<ref name="ComebackPOY">{{cite web | title = Pennington Named Comeback Player Of The Year And Offensive Player Of The Week; Injury Update | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6304&lid=6304 | accessdate = 19 January 2009 }}</ref> Pennington led the NFL with a 67.4 completion percentage and was second in the NFL with a 97.4 passer rating.<ref name="ComebackPOY"/> He threw for a career-high 3,653 yards, 19 touchdowns and just seven interceptions.<ref name="ComebackPOY"/>
In January 2009, three Dolphins rookies were selected to the [[Pro Football Writers Association]]'s All-Rookie Team.<ref name="AllRookieTeam">{{cite web | title = Long, Langford And Carpenter Named To NFL's All-Rookie Team | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6324 | accessdate = 19 January 2009 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20090121123459/http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=6324 |archivedate = January 21, 2009|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Earning selections were offensive tackle [[Jake Long]], defensive end [[Kendall Langford]] and placekicker [[Dan Carpenter]].<ref name="AllRookieTeam"/>
The first overall pick in the [[2008 NFL Draft]], Long started all 16 games for the Dolphins at left tackle.<ref name="AllRookieTeam"/> A third-round pick out of [[Hampton Pirates football|Hampton]], Langford started 14 of the 16 games in which he played as a rookie and recorded 31 tackles and two sacks.<ref name="AllRookieTeam"/> Undrafted out of [[Montana Grizzlies football|Montana]], Carpenter went 21-for-25 (84 percent) on field goals and made all 40 extra-point attempts.<ref name="AllRookieTeam"/>
==Playoffs== ===Game summaries=== ====AFC Wild Card: vs. Baltimore Ravens==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Ravens''' |R1=3 |R2=10 |R3=7 |R4=7 |RT=27 |Home=Dolphins |H1=3 |H2=0 |H3=0 |H4=6 |HT=9 |stadium= [[Dolphin Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 79 Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 65,859 |referee= [[Ed Hochuli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Jim Nantz]] and [[Phil Simms]] }} Entering the postseason as the AFC's #3 seed, the Dolphins began their playoff run at home in the AFC Wild Card Round, with a Week 7 rematch against the #6 [[Baltimore Ravens]]. Miami would deliver the game's first points with rookie kicker [[Dan Carpenter]]'s 19-yard field goal. The Ravens would later respond with a 23-yard field goal from kicker [[Matt Stover]]. Baltimore would take the lead with safety [[Ed Reed]] returning a [[Chad Pennington]] interception 64 yards for a touchdown. The Ravens would then close out the half with Stover's 31-yard field goal.
Baltimore would increase their lead in the third quarter with running back [[Le'Ron McClain]]'s 8-yard touchdown run. The Dolphins tried to come back in the fourth quarter as Pennington completed a 2-yard touchdown pass to running back [[Ronnie Brown]] (with a failed PAT), but the Ravens would pull away as quarterback [[Joe Flacco]] got a 5-yard touchdown run.
With the loss, Miami's impressive turnaround season ended with an overall record of 11â6.
Despite having only 16 turnovers throughout the entire regular season, the Dolphins committed 5 turnovers (4 interceptions and a lost fumble).
